Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under Massachusetts law to modify custody and parenting-time orders affecting a child who is domiciled in Massachusetts, and under the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (provisions governing divorce and related orders affecting custody, visitation and support).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119 (general provisions regarding protection and welfare of children) (as applicable to child welfare considerations).

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (discussing fundamental parental rights and deference to parents regarding child-rearing decisions).
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes as a matter of substantive due process the “fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children” and invalidates Washington’s visitation statute because it failed to give deference or “special weight” to a fit parent’s child‑rearing decisions. The Court’s analysis centers on the need to presume that fit parents act in their children’s best interests and criticizes the statute and trial court for failing to accord that deference. Thus Troxel is properly cited for fundamental parental rights and required deference to parental child‑rearing decisions.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … [S]o long as a parent adequately cares for his or her children (i.e., is fit), there will normally be no reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family… And, if a fit parent's decision of the kind at issue here becomes subject to judicial review, the court must accord at least some special weight to the parent's own determination.”

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (standards for modification of parental rights in dependency proceedings; parental interest recognized).
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly concerns termination of parental rights in a state dependency/neglect framework and sets a constitutional standard (clear and convincing evidence) for such termination proceedings. It expressly recognizes the fundamental liberty interest of parents in the care, custody, and management of their children, emphasizing that this interest does not evaporate even when parents have lost temporary custody. Although the case is about initial termination rather than later modification, it is properly cited for parental due process standards in dependency proceedings and for recognition of the parental interest.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State. Even when blood relationships are strained, parents retain a vital interest in preventing the irretrievable destruction of their family life… When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures.”

Lassiter v. Department of Social Service.raw_text: Lassiter v. Department of Social Services, 452 U.S. 18 (1981)
Lassiter v. Department of Social Service.proposition: Lassiter v. Department of Social Services, 452 U.S. 18 (1981) (procedural protections where parental rights are at stake).
Lassiter v. Department of Social Service.case_name: Lassiter v. Department of Social Servs. of Durham Cty.
Lassiter v. Department of Social Service.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses what procedural protections—specifically the right to appointed counsel—are required as a matter of due process when the State seeks to terminate parental rights. Although the Court ultimately rejects a categorical right to counsel and adopts a case‑by‑case standard, it thoroughly analyzes the nature and importance of the parental interest and the due process balancing required, making it an appropriate citation for the general proposition about procedural protections where parental rights are at stake.
Lassiter v. Department of Social Service.relevant_excerpt: “This Court’s decisions have by now made plain beyond the need for multiple citation that a parent’s desire for and right to ‘the companionship, care, custody, and management of his or her children’ is an important interest that ‘undeniably warrants deference and, absent a powerful countervailing interest, protection.’ … A parent’s interest in the accuracy and justice of the decision to terminate his or her parental status is, therefore, a commanding one…. [W]e therefore adopt the standard found appropriate in Gagnon v. Scarpelli, and leave the decision whether due process calls for the appointment of counsel…to be answered in the first instance by the trial court…”}

Matter of Custody of a Minor.raw_text: Matter of Custody of a Minor
Matter of Custody of a Minor.proposition: Matter of Custody of a Minor (Mass. SJC decisions and Mass. App. Ct. decisions addressing best-interests factors and modification) — see, e.g., cases interpreting the best-interests standard and modification for material change in circumstances.
